<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/52  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 411, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
February/March 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 213, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 556, 90]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows a thin cylindrical metal rod of length \(L\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 102, 831, 173]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 191, 532, 208]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 221, 920, 255]]<|/det|>
One end of the rod is hit with a hammer. A stationary sound wave is set up within the rod. The rod vibrates at its resonant frequency \(f\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 268, 920, 301]]<|/det|>
A microphone placed at the other end of the rod detects the sound wave emitted from the rod. The frequency of the detected sound is also \(f\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 314, 527, 332]]<|/det|>
A number of rods of different length are available.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 345, 559, 363]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(f\) is related to \(L\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 367, 556, 403]]<|/det|>
\[2fL^n = \sqrt{\frac{E}{\rho}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 406, 635, 425]]<|/det|>
where \(\rho\) is the density of the metal, and \(E\) and \(n\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 438, 685, 456]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(f\) and \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 469, 625, 487]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 500, 700, 518]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine values for \(E\) and \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 531, 384, 549]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 562, 393, 579]]<|/det|>
· the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 586, 410, 603]]<|/det|>
· the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 610, 348, 626]]<|/det|>
· the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 633, 351, 650]]<|/det|>
· the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 656, 448, 673]]<|/det|>
· any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 463, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates an electrical circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
A power supply with negligible internal resistance is connected to six resistors, each of resistance Z, and a resistor of resistance \(R\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 149, 759, 453]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 467, 532, 486]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 500, 475, 517]]<|/det|>
The current measured by the ammeter is \(I\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 530, 547, 548]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated for different values of \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 561, 571, 579]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(I\) and \(R\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 592, 561, 610]]<|/det|>
\[E = 3IR + 4IZ\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 624, 635, 642]]<|/det|>
where \(E\) is the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 653, 144, 672]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 652, 648, 677]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(\frac{1}{I}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(R\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 685, 611, 703]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 870, 917, 889]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 902, 917, 920]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 919, 920, 936]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 490, 89]]<|/det|> Values of \(R\) and \(I\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 102, 541, 120]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 131, 784, 445]]<|/det|>
\(R/\mathrm {k}\Omega\)\(I/\upmu \mathrm {A}\)\(\frac {1}{I}/\mathrm {A}^{-1}\)
1.25225±5
2.55185±5
3.90160±5
5.25140±5
6.55125±5
7.80115±5
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 465, 567, 496]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \(\frac{1}{I}/\mathrm {A}^{-1}\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 494, 479, 520]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in \(\frac{1}{I}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 500, 920, 517]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 540, 144, 559]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 537, 180, 559]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 534, 692, 562]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{I}/\mathrm {A}^{-1}\) against \(R/\mathrm {k}\Omega\). Include error bars for \(\frac{1}{I}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 540, 920, 559]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 571, 180, 590]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 570, 920, 604]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 586, 920, 605]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 617, 180, 636]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 616, 920, 650]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 802, 920, 821]]<|/det|>
gradient = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 210, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
\[y\mathrm{-intercept} = .................................................... [2]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 241, 146, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 241, 180, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 241, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of \(E\) and \(Z\). Include appropriate units.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 411, 917, 429]]<|/det|>
\[E = ............................................................\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 443, 920, 460]]<|/det|>
\[Z = ............................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 459, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 489, 181, 508]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 489, 549, 508]]<|/det|>
Determine the percentage uncertainty in \(Z\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 628, 920, 646]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty in \(Z =\) .................................................... %

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[868, 636, 920, 655]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 675, 146, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 675, 900, 694]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated. Determine the resistance \(R\) that gives a value of \(I\) of \(0.10 \text{mA}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 828, 920, 846]]<|/det|>
\[R = ............................................................ \Omega \]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 860, 920, 878]]<|/det|>
